messages.content:
Good morning, and what better way of making this morning even more beautiful than with another question 😄

My goal is to provably generate a random/pseudorandom number. In other words, I'm seeking a way to verifiably demonstrate a (pseudo)random generation of a number in an O1JS circuit/ZkProgram.

The goal would be to enable a user to provably demonstrate that the number that they have generated was a result of them running a pseudorandom number generation algorithm, or that the number is pseudorandom due to the way it is obtained.

One solution that I've been devising is using a Smart Contract that is used as a trusted source of randomness. The Smart Contract would expose a seed, which is the hash of a combination of network on-chain values, such as the block hash, timestamp and Mina in circulation (https://docs.minaprotocol.com/zkapps/o1js/on-chain-values#network-reference). Each user could then provably generate a pseudorandom numbers by computing Poseidon.hash(onChainSeed, sender public key, nonce). This construction contains a pseudorandom seed from the smart contract, a nonce that is unique for all blockchain users, and a "local nonce" which remains a private input for each user, and allows them to generate multiple pseudorandom numbers.

The solution described above would allow for a pseudorandom number generation scheme that does not require an Oracle, and each new block in the blockchain would refresh the seed and start a new random number generation round, and as such, providing a freshness guarantee for those numbers.

Is the solution above sound? Does it provide sufficient entropy? What other approaches exist for this?

Thank you!

embeds.title: Mina Documentation
embeds.description: Website for documentation about Mina Protocol

messages.content: what you're looking for is a VRF
Thank you, but VRF is a general topic, I'm seeking a concrete solution for O1JS, which may or may not involve a VRF. And there is another point regarding the entropy of the described soution 😄

any concrete solution, according to your requirements, will be implementing the functionality of a VRF, right? I highly recommend reading the OG paper about VRF, it helps clarify a lot of the background: https://dash.harvard.edu/bitstream/handle/1/5028196/Vadhan_VerifRandomFunction.pdf

As to your concrete question, you can safely rely on the entropy of the epoch seeds (see Mina.getNetworkState), which are protected by consensus and seed the VRF used for slot leader selection (can’t get any more secure than this).

Truthfully, I think you don’t need a dedicated smart contract for this, I believe you can just write a provable method that pulls in the bits of network state needed and hides the nonce.
(the paper talks about the construction you propose btw)

Thanks @ember!

> Truthfully, I think you don’t need a dedicated smart contract for this, I believe you can just write a provable method that pulls in the bits of network state needed and hides the nonce.

But isn't reading the network state only achievable within a smart contract? How would a plan ZkProgram get access to that information? More importantly, it would still require an on-chain verifier, and that would mean either having a smart contract or using Mina's verifier directly somewhow
definitely needs to be a part of a smart contract! i just think it doesn’t need to be deployed to its own account to support the functionality, I _think_ the way you propose can be fully stateless

@ember True! This can be used to generate random numbers for arbitrary needs. I was thinking of this in the context of a bigger solution, where a user can prove on-chain that they generated a pseudorandom number. This is the part that would require the smart contract to verify and accept the user-proposed number 🙂
To address the additional question, a ZkProgram can take a seed as input but only have it constrained by its caller to be equal to the current network seed
this leads to a limitation of generating one number per block, unless there is some kind of coordination among the generators?

Perhaps my explanation wasn't clear. I'll try again below.

1. Smart contract fixes the seed. Let's say seed = Poseidon.hash(block_hash, timestamp, ...). This defines a round. A round is the lifetime of a block as the HEAD of the chain. This means that the duration of a round is determined by the time taken to produce a single block, or a number of blocks (this defining an epoch)
2. Each user generates a randon muber using Poseidon.hash(seed, public key, nonce)
3. `seed ` is the source of entropy. `public key` is a per-user nonce, ensuring that no two users start with PRNG in exaclty the same state. `nonce ` is a number chosen by the user, and it allows it to generate 2^256 (approx) random values per round
How do I verify a generation, when the chain does not keep any history, and thus the seeds from previous blocks are inaccessible?

I don't believe keeping history is necessary. The smart contract verifies wether the user indeed used Poseidon.Hash(Poseidon.hash(block_hash, timestamp, ...), public key, nonce) to generate the number, and the verification is only successful in this case.

As such, each number accepted by the verifier is proven to be pseudorandom, and can be used a part of further computations. Imagine a smart contract calling this smart contract to get a random number for the current round.
the history is visible to contracts in any case as a merkle list
membership proofs in a merkle list are not succinct, they grow with the size of the history. a separate nonsuccinct indexer would be required to keep those up to date
(and sequencing the mutations to the merkle list raises the same problem I did above of one generation per block, absent coordination)
you make a proof using pickles
/ kimchi

think about the statement you need to prove, having a valid membership proof from the past doesn’t give you the information you need to know to ensure that the current state includes that past state, without all the intermediate hashes between them
I'm not sure what you mean, you have a proof where you can start with the base case (state is head of list), then you do one step at a time, cons-ing a new head
of course you need to keep track of the blockchain, i.e. you need an archive
thus, not succinct
this is the one-number-per-block problem i was mentioning earlier
what do you mean not succinct?
the S in SNARK, or as in the mina whitepaper https://minaprotocol.com/wp-content/uploads/technicalWhitepaper.pdf.
Sure, how does that pertain to this?

> How do I verify a generation, when the chain does not keep any history, and thus the seeds from previous blocks are inaccessible? 

It doesn't matter from the perspective of a smart contract whether the chain "keeps" the history any more it does on e.g. Ethereum

at the moment of generation, to prove to a third party the freshness & correctness, the third party needs to  verify the mina blockchain proof for the block including the txn that asked the smart contract to certify a number.

at future times, the third party also needs to know that the historical block referenced in the blockchain proof is an ancestor of the current chain. this "ancestor proof" is not a primitive provided by mina, it's something that needs to be maintained separately and updated for every single block.
Ah OK, yes, I agree on that.
